awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Novel Respiratory Bag-Valve-Mask Resuscitator
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the development of a novel resuscitator to ventilate patients with respiratory failure or cardiac arrest.  With almost 300,000 cases of out-of-hospital cardiac arrest and approximately 350,000 in-hospital cases each year in the United States, a modest increase of just 5% in the number of patients surviving cardiac arrest would correspond to more than 33,000 additional lives saved. In 2017, the combined direct and indirect costs of deaths from out-of-hospital cardiac arrest for patients under 50 years of age to be $455 billion, with an estimate of $1.8 trillion for all deaths from cardiac arrest. On this basis, every 1% increase in the out-of-hospital cardiac arrest survival rate would result in a $4.5 billion cost saving to the United States economy.The proposed project addresses the technical challenges associated with a novel device.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project advance translation of a bag-valve-mask resuscitator that restricts the volume, pressure, and rate of ventilation to safe levels for any patient, from infant to adult. The goal of the project is to design and test a fully functioning prototype that incorporates an easy-to-use mechanism for quickly and simultaneously adjusting both the maximum volume of air delivered and the maximum pressure, and a mechanism for restricting ventilation rate. The project objectives are:  (1)  prototype and test a novel dial-operated mechanism for simultaneous volume and pressure control; (2) test a flow-based mechanism for restricting the ventilation rate; (3) compare the prototype performance with that of a standard bag-valve-mask resuscitator used by a group of trained medical personnel. Successful completion of this project will result in a fully functional prototype, a valuable set of data on the device performance, and important feedback from end-users on design, ease of use, and device functionality to inform future modifications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Compact Medical's mission is to save lives by reducing injury from inappropriate ventilation during emergency resuscitation. The aim of the company's work in this Phase I study was to demonstrate the technical and commercial feasibility of the Butterfly BVM, an innovative bag-valve-mask (BVM) resuscitation device that safeguards patients against lung injury. With invaluable Phase I SBIR support from the National Science Foundation, the team at Compact Medical has successfully transitioned a humble early-concept technology into a mature device that has passed proof-of-concept testing and proven itself to be, in many cases, superior to the products it is intending to replace.

The original objective of this NSF Phase I project was to deliver a bag-valve-mask with all the features typically found in a such a device, plus the ability for one unifying device to resuscitate four different sizes of patient: infant, child, small adult, and large adult. At the conclusion of the Phase I work, the Butterfly BVM's design has been enhanced and can adjust tidal volumes to match 9 published infant and pediatric Broselow categories and 4 adult ideal body weight groups. The device also possesses safeguards not found in a traditional bag-valve-mask. This includes a built-in and adjustable peak inspiratory pressure valve which protects the patient from high pressures, an integrated positive end-expiratory pressure valve which maintains appropriate pressures within the patient, and a rate control mechanism that helps to provide ventilation rates in line with published standards. Compact Medical has completed baseline benchtop testing with a prototype of the Butterfly BVM, and this device has undergone an early human factors trial with actual lifesavers. In this trial, lifesavers delivered more physiologically appropriate tidal volumes to simulated adult and pediatric patient mannequins with the Butterfly BVM than with a traditional bag-valve-mask. Furthermore, despite the device's complexity over the traditional bag-valve-mask, lifesavers in the study were able to rapidly learn to adjust the Butterfly BVM's settings to meet changing clinical needs. Compact Medical is anticipating publishing this data in a peer-reviewed journal in the coming months. This work has helped to develop an intuitive and innovative device to someday give lifesavers unprecedented reassurance when providing care to critically ill patients. Importantly, over the course of this work, two large groups of lifesavers with exposure to both the Butterfly BVM and a traditional bag-valve-mask demonstrated a preference for the new device suggesting a strong product-market fit.

The results of this Phase I work exceeded the team's expectations. Compact Medical humbly recognizes the immense assistance received from the National Science Foundation, United States taxpayers, and other parties. While technical, manufacturing, and scale challenges remain, this work has converted a promising concept into a mature technology that is ready to begin acceleration toward product launch.


Last Modified: 08/30/2022
Modified by: Adam C Scott
